title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Jar That Fixed My Winter Face
body:
Okay so I’m just gonna write this down because I keep telling people about it and sounding like a weirdo. It’s late, I’m on my couch, and my hands smell like… herbs? Not bad herbs. Good herbs. I just put on this tallow balm stuff. The lavender one.

Let me back up.

My skin hates winter. Hates it. It gets this tight, itchy feeling, like it’s two sizes too small. My knuckles crack. My cheeks get red and angry. I’ve tried everything in the fancy blue bottles. Stuff that costs more than my electric bill. It would feel okay for an hour and then my skin would just suck it up and go back to being thirsty and mad. I was scrolling on my phone one night, probably around midnight, and I saw this thing about beef tallow skincare. Like, fat. From a cow. For your face. I thought it was a joke. Or some extreme homesteader thing. But the pictures of the balm looked… nice? Creamy. And the reviews were all these normal people saying it saved their skin. I was desperate. And curious. So I clicked on this little Etsy shop and got the whipped tallow balm. The lavender scented one. Because if I’m gonna rub cow fat on my face, I at least want it to smell nice.

It arrived on a Tuesday. I remember because it was trash day and the truck was super loud.

## What Is This Stuff Even Made Of?

Right, so tallow balm. It sounds medieval. It’s basically rendered fat from grass-fed cows, whipped up until it’s this super soft, kind of fluffy cream. They make this one in France, which feels fancy until you remember it’s still cow fat. But here’s the science part I read that made me go “huh, maybe”: it’s really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So instead of just sitting on top of your skin like a lot of lotions, this tallow balm stuff actually sinks in. It’s like it speaks the same language as your skin. It’s good for super dry patches, chapped lips, even stuff like psoriasis. I don’t have that, but my winter face might as well be a desert, so.

I was skeptical. Very.

## Opening the Jar For the First Time

The jar is small. Like, fits in the palm of your hand small. It came in a little box. I opened it at my kitchen counter. The lid was on tight. I got it open and just… looked at it. It’s this off-white cream, super smooth looking. I poked it. It was cool. And then I smelled it.

This is the part I can never get right when I tell people.

It doesn’t smell like a candle. Or like fake lavender air freshener. It’s not strong or perfume-y. It smells… clean? And green. And a little bit like the inside of an old wooden cabinet where someone kept dried flowers. It’s a calm smell. It’s not screaming “LAVENDER!!” at you. It’s more like the smell is sitting quietly in the corner of the room. It’s a timeless herbal smell, I guess. But that sounds too fancy. It just smells like something you’d want to put on before bed. A relaxing smell. Soothing. It made the whole “cow fat” idea way less strange.

I scooped a tiny bit out with my finger. It felt rich. I rubbed it between my palms to warm it up and then just went for it—smushed it all over my face. My skin drank it. Like, immediately. No greasy film. No shiny residue. My face just felt… normal. Hydrated. Not tight. Not itchy. I stood there for a minute waiting for it to feel gross. It never did.

## How This Scented Tallow Balm Fits My Messy Routine

I’m not a 10-step routine person. I forget. I get tired. My routine is basically: try to remember to take makeup off, put something on my face, go to bed.

This lavender tallow balm became my one thing.

I use it at night. After I wash my face, when my skin is still a little damp. I scoop out a little—you don’t need much—warm it up, and massage it in. The scent is the best part. It’s not a strong perfume, it’s just this gentle, calming cloud. It’s become my signal that the day is over. My brain goes, “Oh, that smell. Time to shut off.” It’s genuinely sleep-promoting. If I’m feeling wound up or anxious, the ritual of putting it on helps. The smell, the feel of it, it’s like a little pause button. It’s my night cream now.

Sometimes I use it in the morning too, if it’s really cold and windy out. Just a tiny dab. And on my hands. My knuckles haven’t cracked once this winter. Not once.

I keep the jar on my nightstand. It’s simple. I look forward to using it. That’s a weird thing to say about a skincare product, but it’s true. It’s a little moment of nice.

## So, Did This Natural Lavender Skincare Thing Actually Work?

Yeah. It did.

I didn’t expect it to. I thought it might be a greasy mess. But my skin is different. It’s not “perfect”—I still get a zit sometimes, I’m in my 30s, whatever—but it’s balanced. It’s not freaking out. The dry, flaky patches on my cheeks are gone. Completely. My face just feels… comfortable. Like it’s not fighting me anymore. I’ve even used this tallow balm on my lips when they’re chapped and it works better than any lip balm I’ve bought.

I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom too, for her super dry elbows. She texted me last week like “what is this magic fat?”.

I’m not saying it’s a miracle. But for my winter skin? It’s the only thing that’s made a real, lasting difference. It just works. I don’t know the fancy words for it. My skin is happy. I’m happy. That’s the review.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Seems like it, yeah. From what I understand, it’s really compatible with our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs well and doesn’t just sit there. It’s like giving your skin something it actually recognizes and can use.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores pretty easy. Because it absorbs and mimics sebum, it doesn’t seem to just block things up. My skin feels clear, not congested.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It’s hard to describe! It’s not a strong, artificial lavender. It’s more herbal and clean. Gentle. Calming. It smells like a quiet, relaxing night, not a flower shop.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, especially in the winter, this scented tallow balm might be worth a shot. I got mine from a small shop on Etsy. I’ll probably order another one soon. My elbows haven't been this smooth since... I don't know when. So yeah. It just works.
